file_metadata.title: Planarian Regeneration as a Model of Anatomical Homeostasis: Recent Progress in Biophysical and Computational Approaches

chunks.text: Planarian flatworms exhibit remarkable regenerative capabilities, posing fundamental questions about pattern control and its relationship to the genome.  Despite advances in molecular genetics, key mysteries remain, including how fragments establish correct polarity, the lack of stable patterning mutants, and the stability of anatomy despite genomic variability. A thought experiment involving hybrid planaria with different head shapes highlights the lack of predictive models for large-scale anatomical outcomes.
chunks.chunk_summary: Planarian regeneration presents unsolved puzzles regarding polarity establishment, mutant absence, anatomical stability despite genomic variation, and the lack of predictive models for large-scale shape outcomes.

chunks.text: Planarian regeneration can be viewed through the lens of biological computation, pattern control, and the genotype-phenotype relation.  This review focuses on recent developments in understanding the physiological signals underlying pattern control, including bioelectric and neurotransmitter-mediated signaling, and advances in computational modeling for understanding the algorithms controlling planarian shape.
chunks.chunk_summary: This review explores planarian regeneration from a computational and physiological perspective, focusing on bioelectric signaling, neurotransmitters, and computational modeling to understand pattern control.

chunks.text: Regeneration requires cells to make patterning decisions based on non-local information, suggesting a "pattern memory" and goal-directed processes.  Planaria were among the earliest models suggesting roles for ion- and voltage-mediated processes in regeneration.  Advances in developmental bioelectricity have led to hypotheses about ion channels guiding cell behavior and the relationship between multicellular electric circuits and developmental morphospace.
chunks.chunk_summary: Planarian regeneration involves a "pattern memory" and goal-directed processes, with bioelectric signaling playing a key role in guiding cell behavior and shaping morphology.

chunks.text: Non-neural tissues may perform information processing using ion flows, similar to graded potentials in neurons.  Ion channels and neurotransmitters are evolutionarily ancient and used for information processing and communication in various organisms.  Classical research highlighted the role of bioelectric circuits in regeneration, with Morgan and Child postulating electrical polarity and physiological gradients in pattern control.
chunks.topic: Bioelectric signaling and its evolutionary history
chunks.chunk_summary: Non-neural tissues may use ion flows for information processing, with ion channels and neurotransmitters having ancient evolutionary origins in regulating individual and group behaviors, as highlighted by early research on planarian regeneration.

chunks.text: Recent work has probed the role of bioelectric components in planarian regeneration.  Manipulating bioelectric gradients can produce double-headed or no-headed planaria, demonstrating the instructive role of bioelectricity in AP polarity.  Gap junctions are crucial for network function and have been implicated in stem cell dynamics and head/tail polarity.
chunks.chunk_summary: Manipulating bioelectric gradients and gap junctions affects head/tail polarity and stem cell dynamics in planaria, highlighting their role in pattern control.

chunks.text: Neurotransmitters, ancient signaling molecules, play a role in planarian regenerative control.  Research has identified roles for serotonin, voltage-gated calcium channels, and other neurotransmitter machinery in determining AP polarity.  New fluorescent sensors and light-based techniques will further advance this area.
chunks.chunk_summary: Neurotransmitters, including serotonin and calcium channels, are involved in planarian AP polarity, with new tools promising further insights.

chunks.text: Bioelectric networks can enable outcomes that diverge from genetic defaults, as seen in Xenopus melanoma and brain defect studies.  In planaria, modulating bioelectrical connectivity can induce head shapes resembling other species, suggesting bioelectric networks store pattern information.  This change is not permanent, resembling short-term memory without consolidation.
chunks.chunk_summary: Bioelectric networks can override genetic defaults, as shown by inducing different species' head shapes in planaria, suggesting a form of bioelectrically encoded pattern memory.

chunks.text: Regeneration can be modeled as pattern homeostasis, a TOTE loop minimizing the difference between current and target morphology.  This implies a stored setpoint representing the target morphology.  Experiments with 1-octanol produced double-headed planaria that regenerated as double-headed perpetually, demonstrating the possibility of overwriting the pattern memory.
chunks.chunk_summary: Planarian regeneration as pattern homeostasis suggests a stored target morphology setpoint, which can be overwritten, as demonstrated by permanently double-headed planaria induced by 1-octanol.

chunks.text: The permanent double-headed state can be reset to single-headed using ion pump blockers.  "Cryptic" worms, appearing normal but regenerating double-headed upon cutting, demonstrate latent, aberrant pattern memory revealed by depolarized tissues.  This illustrates how a normal body can support distinct bodyplan encodings, fulfilling the properties of memory: encoding, stability, and rewritability.
chunks.chunk_summary: Planarian pattern memory can be reset, with "cryptic" worms demonstrating latent, aberrant memory encoded in bioelectric patterns, highlighting the encoding, stability, and rewritability of this memory.

chunks.text: Planaria offer examples of rewriting anatomical setpoints without genomic editing.  Future work should focus on the interplay of transcriptional, chromatin-based, and physiological layers to understand stochasticity and stability of target morphology.  The key challenge is converting cell-level information into an understanding of large-scale anatomical attractor states and shape homeostasis.
chunks.chunk_summary: Future research should investigate the interplay of different regulatory layers to understand the stochasticity and stability of planarian target morphology and how cell-level information translates to large-scale anatomical states.

chunks.text: Computational approaches are crucial for understanding planarian regeneration.  New databases and simulation environments are emerging, alongside machine learning tools for model discovery.  This section reviews the current state of computational models, focusing on AP polarity, and discusses tools for model discovery and their application to planarian regeneration.
chunks.chunk_summary: Computational approaches, including databases, simulations, and machine learning, are essential for understanding planarian regeneration, particularly AP polarity and model discovery.

chunks.text: Current computational models of planarian regeneration explore gradients, reaction-diffusion systems, and neural network dynamics.  Gradient models, while valuable, struggle to explain polarity establishment in bisected worms.  Reaction-diffusion models, successful in other systems, face challenges in explaining planarian-specific features.  Neural network models offer a promising approach for capturing complex interactions and decision-making.
chunks.chunk_summary: Existing computational models, including gradient, reaction-diffusion, and neural network approaches, have varying success in explaining planarian regeneration, with neural networks offering a promising avenue for capturing complex dynamics.

chunks.text: Simulation environments are crucial for testing models against experimental data.  Existing simulators focus on biochemical factors or bioelectric/physiological processes in a spatialized virtual tissue.  PlanForm is a bioinformatics tool for formalizing planarian experiments and outcomes, enabling model testing and knowledge accumulation.
chunks.chunk_summary: Simulation environments and databases like PlanForm are essential for testing planarian regeneration models against experimental data and formalizing knowledge in the field.

chunks.text: Machine learning approaches are increasingly important for model discovery in complex biological systems like planaria.  Evolutionary search algorithms have been used to uncover biochemical networks matching key regeneration experiments.  These approaches can identify unknown components, and computational techniques can suggest putative identities for testing.
chunks.chunk_summary: Machine learning, particularly evolutionary algorithms, can assist in discovering complex regulatory networks in planarian regeneration, including identifying unknown components and suggesting testable hypotheses.

chunks.text: Model inversion, predicting interventions for desired outcomes, is crucial for regenerative medicine.  An example is the automated discovery of a bioelectric and serotonergic network explaining melanoma conversion in Xenopus.  This approach identified interventions to break concordance and produce partially-hyperpigmented animals, demonstrating the potential for model-driven control of morphology.
chunks.chunk_summary: Model inversion, predicting interventions for specific outcomes, is crucial, as demonstrated by the discovery of interventions controlling melanoma conversion in Xenopus, highlighting the potential for model-driven morphological control.

chunks.text: Planaria are a valuable model for studying regeneration, bridging evolutionary biology, biomedicine, bioengineering, and information science.  They offer a "computational medium" for studying pattern control and the relationship between genome and anatomy.  Future work should focus on understanding how tissues store pattern information and how evolution exploits physiological plasticity.
chunks.chunk_summary: Planaria are a powerful model system for studying regeneration, bridging multiple disciplines and offering insights into pattern control, genome-anatomy relationships, and the role of physiological plasticity in evolution.

chunks.text: Planaria with normal configurations can store and regenerate to different target morphologies.  Bioelectrical re-specification of pattern memory has implications for bodyplan evolution.  Future research should integrate molecular genetics, dynamical systems theory, biophysics, and computation to understand planarian regeneration.
chunks.chunk_summary: Future planarian research should integrate multiple perspectives to understand how normal planaria store different target morphologies, the role of bioelectricity in pattern memory and bodyplan evolution, and the complex dynamics of regeneration.

chunks.text: Future research should expand beyond AP polarity and head number to understand actual shape in three dimensions.  Molecular marker expression and anatomy can diverge, requiring clear criteria for determining structural identity.  Understanding variability and robustness in planarian regeneration are key challenges with implications for biomedicine and robotics.
chunks.chunk_summary: Future research should prioritize understanding 3D shape, address the divergence between molecular markers and anatomy, and investigate variability and robustness in planarian regeneration, with implications for biomedicine and robotics.

chunks.text: Biologists need to expand their toolkits and conceptual frameworks to understand planarian regeneration.  Connectionist and Least Action/Active Inference ideas are potential paradigms for understanding pattern memory.  New bioinformatics tools and artificial intelligence will be crucial for extracting insights from large datasets and advancing biomedicine.
chunks.chunk_summary: Expanding toolkits and conceptual frameworks, including connectionist and Least Action/Active Inference ideas, along with bioinformatics and AI, are crucial for advancing understanding of planarian regeneration and its implications for biomedicine.

chunks.text: This research was supported by the Allen Discovery Center, NIH, G. Harold and Leila Y. Mathers Charitable Foundation, NSF, W. M. KECK Foundation, and Templeton World Charity Foundation. The paper is dedicated to C. M. Child, G. Marsh, and H. W. Beams, pioneers in planarian regeneration physiology.
chunks.chunk_summary: The research was funded by various organizations and is dedicated to pioneers in planarian regeneration physiology.

chunks.text: Experimental data implicating endogenous bioelectric signal roles in morphogenesis across various species and model systems, including cellular polarization, migration, patterning, growth control, neural differentiation, regeneration, and craniofacial patterning.
chunks.chunk_summary: Bioelectric signals play diverse roles in morphogenesis across various species, influencing processes like cellular polarization, migration, patterning, and regeneration.

chunks.text: Ion channels and pumps proteins implicated in patterning by genetic screens, including their morphogenetic roles and loss-of-function phenotypes in various species, such as Arabidopsis, Drosophila, Mouse, Human, C. Elegans, Xenopus, chick, and zebrafish.
chunks.topic: Ion channels and pumps in patterning
chunks.chunk_summary: Genetic screens have identified various ion channels and pumps with crucial roles in patterning across different species, revealing their impact on morphogenesis and developmental defects.

chunks.text: Additional ion channels and pumps proteins implicated in patterning by genetic screens, including their morphogenetic roles and loss-of-function phenotypes in various species, such as Zebrafish.
chunks.topic: Ion channels and pumps in patterning
chunks.chunk_summary: Further genetic screens have revealed additional ion channels and pumps involved in patterning, expanding our understanding of their roles in morphogenesis and developmental processes.

chunks.text: Planarian regeneration presents fundamental puzzles of pattern control, including polarity re-scaling, the lack of stable patterning mutants, and the stability of anatomy despite genomic variability. A thought experiment involving hybrid planaria with different head shapes highlights knowledge gaps in understanding head shape determination.
chunks.chunk_summary: Planarian regeneration poses challenges to understanding pattern control, including polarity, mutant absence, anatomical stability, and head shape determination in hybrid scenarios.

chunks.text: Bioelectrically-mediated changes of patterning in planaria demonstrate the instructive role of bioelectric gradients in AP polarity. Modifying these gradients can induce heteromorphoses. Gap junction blockers can induce head shapes resembling other species, with stochastic outcomes related to evolutionary distance.
chunks.chunk_summary: Bioelectric gradients are crucial for planarian patterning, with manipulations inducing heteromorphoses and gap junction blockers causing stochastic head shape changes resembling other species.

chunks.text: Permanent changes to planarian target morphology can be achieved by resetting bioelectrical pattern memories. Gap junction blockers can induce permanent double-headedness, reversible by ion pump drugs. "Cryptic" worms, appearing normal but regenerating double-headed, reveal latent, aberrant pattern memory encoded in bioelectric patterns.
chunks.chunk_summary: Planarian target morphology can be permanently altered by manipulating bioelectric signals, with gap junction blockers inducing double-headedness and revealing latent memory in "cryptic" worms.

chunks.text: Bioinformatics tools are crucial for understanding planarian regeneration. PlanForm formalizes experimental manipulations and outcomes, enabling model testing. Evolutionary search algorithms can uncover gene regulatory networks matching observed data, assisting in pathway discovery and model development.
chunks.chunk_summary: Bioinformatics tools like PlanForm and evolutionary algorithms are essential for analyzing planarian regeneration experiments, discovering gene regulatory networks, and developing predictive models.
